The CARES Act provides expanded protection for unemployment insurance recipients. This includes Pandemic Unemployment Assistance (PUA).

**Pandemic Unemployment Assistance (PUA):**

    + Covers those who usually would not qualify for unemployment (who have worked for a shorter time than two quarters)

    + Covers people who are out of work because of COVID-19 reasons.

    + Provides an additional $600 per week on top of regular benefits (available until July 31, 2020)

    + Provides an additional 13 weeks of benefits, beyond the regular 26 weeks already provided, for a total of 39 weeks of coverage.

    + Benefit rate is based on recent wages.

    + In New York, the current maximum weekly benefit rate is $504. The minimum PUA benefit rate is 50% of the average weekly benefit amount in New York. For January 27, 2020 – March 31, 2020, the minimum benefit rate is $172. For April 1, 2020 – June 30, 2020, the minimum benefit rate is $182.

    + To be eligible for PUA you must first be denied for regular Unemployment Benefits.

    + If {{employee_type}} has been approved for Unemployment Benefits, additional provisions through PUA will be extended to them.

    + **The New York Department of Labor has provided a list of scenarios that would make your {{employee_type}} eligible for PUA.  You can see those [here](https://www.labor.ny.gov/ui/pdfs/pandemic-unemployment-assistance.pdf).**

**Please note** that people who have applied for unemployment insurance have had long wait times. It maybe a while before the person you employ can access these benefits.

**Remember** to document your arrangement with the person you employ. A written agreement is good for the employer and the worker.

Your {{employee_type}} most likely qualifies for some kind of emergency leave under the new COVID rules for Paid Family Leave and Disability.  The kind of leave available depends on the size of the agency:

* **Small Employers** (agencies with 10 or fewer employees as of January 1, 2020, and that had a net annual income less than $1 million last year) must provide job protection for the duration of the quarantine.

* **Medium Employers** (agencies with 11-99 employees as of January 1, 2020, and smaller employers that had a net annual income greater than $1 million last year) must provide job protection for the duration of the quarantine, and at least 5 days of paid sick leave at their full pay rate.

* **Large Employers** (agencies with 100 or more employees as of January 1, 2020) must provide job protection for the duration of the quarantine, and at least 14 days of paid sick leave.

After they've used the paid sick leave required, they can apply for PFL and DB under the normal rules:

* If your {{employee_type}} works a regular schedule of 20 or more hours per week, they're eligible for PFL after 26 consecutive weeks with your agency.
* If your {{employee_type}} works a regular schedule of less than 20 hours per week, they're eligible for PFL after 175 days with your agency, which don't need to be consecutive.
* If your agency is considered a "covered employer", your {{employee_type}} will be eligible for DB after 4 consecutive weeks.
* If your agency is considered a "covered employer", and your {{employee_type}} previously worked for another covered employer, they're eligible for DB on their first day, assuming they didn't have a gap in coverage.
* If your {{employee_type}} carries their own DB coverage, they'd also be eligible.

PFL must be used first, if available, and provides 10 weeks of coverage at **60%** of their full pay rate, up to a maximum of $840.70/week.

Your {{employee_type}} most likely qualifies for leave under both the Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act and the Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act:

* The Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act provides full regular pay for two weeks, up to 80 hours (e.g., if they normally work 20 hours per week, they would receive 40 hours paid leave), because of their need to self-quarantine.

* The Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act provides an additional ten weeks of leave at 2/3 their regular pay, because of their child's school closure.

We say "most likely" because there are some exceptions.  Your agency should be familiar with all the provisions of the FFCRA, including special circumstances that may affect your {{employee_type}}'s eligibility, the leave available, and your responsibilities.  For example, if your agency has fewer than 50 employees, they may qualify for an exemption from the requirement to provide paid leave due to school closings or the unavailability of child care if the leave payments would jeopardize the viability of the business as a going concern. If your agency has more than 500 employees, the FFCRA doesn't apply to them at all.  Please check in with your agency for all specifics.

Assuming your {{employee_type}} is able to request leave, they should provide the agency with a verbal or written request (we recommend written), which should include:

* their name,
* the dates they're requesting leave,
* the name of the doctor who advised them to self-quarantine,
* a statement that they are unable to work because of this self-quarantine,
* the name of the child being cared for,
* the name of the school or child care provider that's closed or unavailable,
* and a statement that no other suitable person is able to provide care for the child
